comments.message: Uploaded patch set 3: New patch set was added with same tree, parent, and commit message as Patch Set 2.

Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)

if this is only for HMC then kindly change the file name to save_area_management_HMC... Something like that.

Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(11 comments)

More typo/formatting suggestions.

These look better if there is a space between them. 

Tested with https://jbt.github.io/markdown-editor/

Author: Ratan Gupta <ratagupt@linux.vnet.ibm.com>
	
Primary assignee: Ratan Gupta
	
Created: 2019-07-10

Otherwise they look like: 
Author: Ratan Gupta ratagupt@linux.vnet.ibm.com Primary assignee: Ratan Gupta Created: 2019-07-10
Have we engaged the DMTF to try to get this included in Redfish?

A little wordy/repeats a lot of the same words. 

Could this be something like:

#### Use cases

- When the virtualization firmware is down, the management console needs to create the logical partitions on a destination system using the configuration details stored in the save area files.

- Restore configuration using the save area files when the system is in an error state. The system may have up to 1,000 LPARs that need to be restored.

Can these just be:
List all the dave area files
Read a specific save area file
Delete a specific save area file
Create a save area file
Update a save area file

(so drop the "Support" and move to
update? Shouldn't you use the resource id to update (e.g. /xyz/openbmc_project/HMC/savearea/<ID>) ? Also a POST is only to create.
POST should return it, It is not clear above in the post will do the change.
This needs to be explained much better. "Save area" needs to be explained.

Save Area - Are we going to support for Ginger (https://github.com/kimchi-project/ginger) which is open source based management console. XCAT already supports by openbmc, Do we need to consider save area management from XCAT perspective?

And from my perspective, Save area should be in host (petitboot or some hidden partition or may be SBE (last option))/HMC side. BMC have very less role in this and traditionally not worked well though.

why do we need ginger support for save area file management?
Will add the content that why we are doing the save area managemnt on the BMC.
ginger is like another HMC, right. Thought of checking whether we need any support for ginger.
Some more introduction on this would be required - for eg why store on the BMC flash?
This is very IBM specific, so need more details.
Please be sure lines do not exceed 80 chars

How about MC allowed to have logical partition data when the virtualization firmware is down. And they can sync once virtualization firmware / hidden partition up and running. 
In fact virtualization firmware / hidden partition  can get more space there when compare to BMC.
Basically moving this function to host and HMC. Not with BMC.
Can we not have OEM related REDFish interface / APIs? REST and REDFISH running same may consume unnecessary memory foot print.

We have single web server which is serving both REST and Redfish interfaces.
We could have gone with redfish but redfish doesn't have the some standard generic file schema so instead of defining the whole new schema we went for REST interface.

Now currently around 1000 partition support is there, Can we scale up to 2000 in the future. 
Are we ready for scaling to bigger number of partitions support?
BMC perspective we need more flash space and it should be fine if we take a decision for 2000 or more partition.

good then. I am fine with that.
+1
Will cover in the event design.
I assume HMC handles all fw update compatibility type issues? i.e. if they change the format of the file between releases, not OpenBMC requirement to clear them out or something?
Will the client require any type of special permission to do this? Like admin?
These interfaces will be accessed only to the user having admin privileges.
I assume just typical REST response codes if 1000 limit or 15MB limit has been exceeded or does HMC require anything special?
Request will fail with typical HTTP code, need to figure it out what would be the HTTP code.

I think I need a little bit more detail here. This is a lot in one sentence. So the app starts up, looks at the filesystem and creates D-bus objects for all files. After that it just monitors via Inotify for changes to the directory (PUT/DELETE type commands) and updates the D-bus objects appropriately?
So there's going to be one D-Bus object per save area file? If you're already doing inotify, then why do you need a D-Bus object?

Wanted to use some common code which does send the redfish event.

Suppose in future we come up and say that there would be a single module in bmcweb which is listening on the D-bus notification and send the redfish event.

Now if we don't go with creation of D-bus object for each file then the module which is Inotifying on the directory can send the event but then sending of event code would be distributed.

With the later approach we can avoid too many D-bus objects, as the primary aim for D-bus should be IPC.

So I will make the change in the doc to not create the D-bus object for each file.
We support currently multiple MC, How we are going to resolve the conflict between 2 MCs trying to update at the same time?

We will handle the synchronization. If the backend service is D-bus service then we don't need to worry as our D-bus services are sequential.
Now with the new approach, we don't need D-bus objects to represent the save area files, we will handle the synchronization in bmcweb itself if needed.

Should we look at making this a more generic service that could potentially be used elsewhere? Basically something that allows external entities to create and manage persistent files on the BMC? Can we think of any other use cases in the future?
I understand that I can make the changes in the rest interface to not tied up with save area but this can be used by BMC for managing other persistent files.
I don't see a strong reason to create D-Bus objects. This could instead be handled by the REST API implementation?
What BMC will be gaining in 15MB space for itself? Is BMC processing capacity help this ?

Save Area management is helping MC and the HOST. BMC is just an intermediate person and here BMC just assist / provide platform to store the date. 

What BMC will gain if we are not doing it? Can we utilize the space / BMC proc. capability for some other things. Or if we are not implementing it, we may be not impacting BMC performance here.

Even if we are fine using openbmc to do save area management, But as this all are customer configuration / confidential data which contains the system configuration etc.. Those details should be accessed / manipulate by HOST only. I strongly feel SBE should do it. They can access to all the resource and they are trusted party, right.
Since IBM host firmware doesn't have any interfaces/storage,It is being stored on the BMC.

One thing we agreed to in the workshop was a single doc with all ibm/v1 interfaces for review. I think we can stick with what we have in here for now but something to think about. (Not sure who ended up with that action item)

We have created the doc which will get updated once we get +1 here in these commits.
As these commits have the REST API,documentation for the REST API, Requirement for the functionality.
One key requirement from workshop was to support atomic PATCH to multiple files in single command.

I thought we need to first see whether it is feasible with REST.
It was not a hard requirement from the Managmenet console Team.
This will be using Redfish event notification I hope?
we seem to go back and forth between just ibm/v1 vs. ibm/powerhmc/v1 in different designs, do we have a decision?
I have updated in the latest PS.
Did we make a decision here which way we will do?

As it is a configuration file, which will not be large one.
I heard from the team the file size would be 200-300 KB, which takes ~3-4 sec to complete the upload.

But we can support the big file when it is needed through async approach.

files. The BMC...

Actually, mostly globally, 'BMC' should be preceded with 'The' or 'the' as above.

Redfish does not have the schema for file management, this is a IBM requirement.

Might be good to document whether this proposal has been taken forward to the DMTF for inclusion in a standard schema.

No, we tried it but we didn't get any response as this is an IBM specific requirement.
So No proposal for DMTF.
why do we need enumerate and not just a /ibm/v1/host/partitions/ returns the list all the partition files

Why is the create/upload the same? In most APIs I see:

GET 	/device-management/devices : Get all devices
POST 	/device-management/devices : Create a new device

GET 	/device-management/devices/{id} : Get the device information identified by "id"
PUT 	/device-management/devices/{id} : Update the device information identified by "id"
DELETE	/device-management/devices/{id} : Delete device by "id"


    Create — POST
    Read/Retrieve — GET
    Update — PUT/PATCH
    Delete — DELETE

Is the partition resouce path /ibm/v1/host/partitions/<objectID> or /ibm/v1/host/partitions/<filename> ?
E.g. /ibm/v1/host/partitions/15 or /ibm/v1/host/partitions/part-15-file

We have the GET, DELETE.
PUT is being used to create/update the resource here.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/630453/put-vs-post-in-rest

In our case <filename> is being specified so we are using PUT here to create/update the resource.
This may not format as expected, since you said there are two ways, try doing a numbered bullet to convey the choice instead of the 'or' between lines.
These points should be in a separate paragraph since they are not part of the two choices
what is the format of these files?

As far as I heard it could be JSON or it could be encrypted one due to security reason.
BMC doesn't need to bother about the file data.
Please add acronyms for this LPAR
I think we need to reconsider this. For 1000 partitions system , each save area file with 200KB, will need more than 15MB size. Actually huge size.
This is the MAX size which may have 200 KB, but not all the files, Most of the files under 10 KB.
There is no D-bus object for these files. We should consider the resourceCreated/resourceDeleted redfish events for notifying the HMC.

I don't see any rationale on why we are using files though.  Does Redfish have schemas for virtual machine management?  If not, why aren't we working to get it added?  Or at least add OEM profiles in the meantime?
Are these files compressible?  Reserving 15MB of space is a lot on a non-eMMC system.  Are you putting a requirement that this feature is only applicable to eMMC?
